block.p: In what would be the largest acquisition ever of a biotechnology company, AstraZeneca agreed Monday to pay $15.6 billion to acquire MedImmune, maker of the FluMist nasal spray flu vaccine.

The deal, with AstraZeneca beating out several rivals, reflected the eagerness of big pharmaceutical companies to obtain new products to maintain growth as older products lose patent protection. So-called biologic drugs made in cell cultures look like a new area of growth to companies like AstraZeneca that have typically made chemical pills.
In what would be the largest acquisition ever of a biotechnology company, AstraZeneca agreed Monday to pay $15.6 billion to acquire MedImmune, maker of the FluMist nasal spray flu vaccine.

The deal, with AstraZeneca beating out several rivals, reflected the eagerness of big pharmaceutical companies to obtain new products to maintain growth as older products lose patent protection. So-called biologic drugs made in cell cultures look like a new area of growth to companies like AstraZeneca that have typically made chemical pills.

The deal also highlighted the growing influence of hedge funds and activist investors in biotechnology. MedImmune, based in Gaithersburg, Md., put itself on the block after Carl C. Icahn threatened a proxy fight to force such an action.

With many biotech companies presumably being worth more to a desperate pharmaceutical company than to public investors, it would not be surprising to see more biotech companies sold -- or forced to be sold.
